Award.AwardTitle: Collaborative Research: A Field-experimental Test for Evolutionary Trait-mediated Indirect Effects in Food Webs
Award.AbstractNarration:
This project utilizes a set of small islands in the northern Caribbean as a model system to understand how interactions between ecological, evolutionary and behavioral factors determine major features of biological communities. The project centers on a large-scale experiment in which presence/absence of large predatory lizards is varied across a series of islands. Large lizards affect smaller, intermediate-size predatory lizards, and the effects cascade down through insect herbivores to the plants. The effects of the top predator on lower trophic levels are mediated largely through effects on the intermediate predator. Such effects can be driven by changes in species densities, but can also depend on specific behavioral and evolutionary traits. The effects of variation in these traits on food-web interactions will be followed over multiple generations. The intermediate predator would be expected to initially decrease but then recover as it behaviorally and evolutionarily adjusts to increased predation risk. The pattern of density change combined with the habitat shift should cause major changes in lower levels of the food web. A comparative study parallels the experiment to determine the food-web pathways generating the experimental results. This study will inform us regarding the interplay between ecology, behavior, and evolution in complex food webs.

This study substantially promotes undergraduate research experiences in field and lab studies and targets groups underrepresented in science. The study also provides graduate-student training and communicates findings to the public via popular articles, public presentations, documentary films, and museum exhibits. Every effort is made to relate this research to applied sciences such as improving agroecosystems, dealing with biological invasions, and preserving species and habitats.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This grant used islands to understand ecological principles, such as how top predators affect the strength and direction of species interactions in food webs, and how such effects can be influenced by intermediate predators via changes in their densities as well as in their

morphological and behavioral traits. Its main project continued an experiment in which a top predator (a curly-tailed lizards) was introduced from natural populations on the adjacent mainland to islands having an intermediate predator (another lizard, the brown anole), with an equal number of unmanipulated islands having the intermediate predator as controls. The brown anole was shown in previous studies to produce many effects on lower levels of the food web, some quite large. How the top predator affects lower levels depends substantially on its effects upon the intermediate predator. Such effects can be on densities, but can also be on behavioral and morphological traits. A primary goal of this experiment was to study how the intermediate predator responded, both ecologically and behaviorally, to the presence of the top predator.

Our first prediction was that the intermediate predator, the brown anole lizard (Anolis sagrei) would become more arboreal in the presence of the predator. This result occurred immediately and continues to this day. We also predicted that the presence of the predator would lead to a decrease in population size of the anoles. However, a further prediction is that as the populations adapt to the presence of the predator, differences in population density between experimental and control treatments will decrease. This, too, is apparent in our data—initially, population differences were quite large between the experimental and control treatments, but over the course of the experiment, the difference decreased.

Also, on islands where curly-tailed lizards are present, brown anoles exhibit a tendency to forage in the "canopy" which includes a higher consumption of fruits (i.e., small berries). However, it should be noted that fruits are relatively rare and highly seasonal at our study site; therefore, it is highly unlikely that they can be a staple of the anole diet. Nevertheless, such a change in foraging might be indicative of the cascading effects of predation, which in this case includes a potential shift in the breadth of the diet of Anolis sagrei.

However, contrary to our predictions, we found no evidence for a decrease in display rate and overall activity by Anolis sagrei in the presence of the predatory lizard. At first glance this result is contrary to the general trend that prey species respond to the presence of predators by reducing their conspicuousness. However, a closer examination of our data shows that in fact, males of Anolis sagrei are reducing their conspicuousness to curly-tailed lizards by modulating their display. We found that males Anolis sagrei modulate the amplitude of their head-bob displays in response to the presence of predators, producing displays that are nearly half the size of those produced in the absence of predators. Because in Anolis sagrei head-bob displays are used to mediate territorial disputes and courtship, this change can affect individual fitness and potentially population dynamics. 

We also hypothesized that shifts in habitat use would have ecosystem effects because the anole populations in the presence of predators would not only be smaller, but also would be using a different part of the habitat. These effects are not yet apparent, perhaps due to the disruptive effects of Hurricanes Irene (2011) and Sandy (2012).

As a result of shifts in habitat use, we predicted that the lizard populations in the presence of predators would evolve shorter limbs, corresponding to the short limbs of anole species adapted to use narrow surfaces. To date, the data do not support this prediction. 

During the course of the experiment, we collaborated with the Howard Hughes Medical Institute to produce a 17-minute film on studying evolutionary adaptation and speciation. The project was filmed at our study site and was based on the work funded by this grant. The film, The Origin of Species: Lizards in an Evolutionary Tree, is freely available on the internet and is widely used in high school and college classrooms throughout the United States and Internationally. At last count, the film had been downloaded more than 200,000 times.
